messageBody:
I am not a testing guru, but I (and our small company) try to be
professional. As part of that our goal is to never release code that is
untested, and we use the available tools to try to accomplish that goal.

I have been reading this thread with interest, and am a little confused
over the argument. I liked Bob Martin's analogy of double entry
bookkeeping, and this may be part of the confusion. As far as I know, it
doesn't matter whether the credit is put into the books first, or the
debit is done first. The value of the practice is that both entries have
to be done, and both must match. We do some test first, and some test
second, but everything gets tested.

In fact our model is a back and forth approach. We write a few tests
based on a use case, and they fail. We write the code to support those
tests, and (in the process) write support code to make the test driven
code compile and pass it's tests. Then we write the tests for the
support code, and the tests for the next use case, this leads to writing
both the code to pass the tests, and some underlying code, which calls
for a few more test cases. These latter tests are driven by the need to
test corner conditions in the support code which may not be exercised by
a specific instance of the use-case driven code.

This back and forth approach seems natural, it reduced context switching
in the design/implement domain, and seems to work well. What am I missing?

Jim

Robert Martin wrote:
> On Jun 1, 2006, at 4:35 AM, junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
>
>> I agree. TDD is a powerful tool, but not as much as "simple
>> testing". If a
>> developer prefers to write code first and tests then, that's
>> perfectly fine
>> with me.
>
> It's not fine with me. In the end, if a developer can show me that s/
> he's got very high test coverage, then I'd accept the effort. But
> I'd also strongly suggest that they write their tests first next time
> to see if they don't find that they get done quicker and with a
> better design.
>
>> The important point here is that this developer needs to agree
>> that writing tests is part of her job. At least to a certain extent.
>
> I disagree that there is a limited responsibility. A developer
> should not release code that they haven't tested. They should not
> release a line of code that they have not tested. Every line, every
> statement, every condition should be tested before the developer
> releases the code. It seems to me that's a minimum professional
> standard. Releasing code that you have not thoroughly tested is,
> simply, unprofessional.
>
